turns.user_message: How do the number of deaths from nuclear power compare to those from coal energy?

The number of deaths attributed to nuclear power is significantly lower than those caused by coal energy when comparing them on a per unit of energy basis. Coal is one of the most hazardous energy sources in terms of human health and safety. From the time of extraction through to combustion, coal is associated with a wide range of fatal and non-fatal impacts.

Coal mining itself is a highly dangerous occupation, with thousands of miners dying in accidents, collapses, and explosions each year worldwide. Beyond the mining process, coal combustion releases harmful pollutants such as sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, particulate matter, and mercury, which contribute to respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, lung cancer, and other serious health conditions. These pollutants lead to millions of premature deaths annually, especially in densely populated areas with high coal reliance.

In contrast, nuclear power has an excellent safety record in terms of direct deaths. There have been only a few major accidents in the history of nuclear power—such as Chernobyl in 1986 and Fukushima in 2011—and while these were tragic, the number of directly attributable deaths is relatively small when compared to the global death toll from coal. Furthermore, nuclear energy does not produce air pollutants like coal, so it doesn't contribute to the millions of deaths from air pollution-related illnesses each year.

When we calculate the death rate per terawatt-hour of energy produced, coal is orders of magnitude more deadly than nuclear. This makes coal the more dangerous option when considering the full lifecycle of the energy source.
